titlePart.entryReference: peculiar to submarines, other than nuclear propulsion,

titlePart.text: Propulsive elements directly acting on water
with rotation axis substantially at right angles to propulsive direction
with blades extending axially from a disc-shaped rotary body
with rotation axis substantially in propulsive direction
having a shrouding ring attached to blades
with means for diminishing cavitation, e.g. supercavitation
Other means for improving propeller efficiency
titlePart.entryReference: water-guiding elements formed by shape of hull

titlePart.text: Flaps, pistons, or the like, reciprocating in propulsive direction
characterised solely by flotation properties, e.g. drums
actuated by control element coaxial with propeller shaft, e.g. the control element being rotary
characterised by use of non-mechanical actuating means, e.g. electrical
characterised by having pitch control conjoint with propulsion-plant control
the pitch being adjustable only when propeller is stationary
Arrangements on vessels of propulsion elements directly acting on water
of paddle wheels, e.g. of stern wheels
of coaxial type, e.g. of counter-rotative type
movably mounted with respect to hull, e.g. "inboard-outboard" type, or adjustable in direction
titlePart.entryReference: arrangements of outboard motors on small boats
movably mounted for steering purposes only

titlePart.text: the ability to move being conferred by gearing in transmission between prime mover and propeller
characterised by being mounted in non-rotating ducts or rings, e.g. adjustable for steering purposes
characterised by being mounted in recesses
of emergency propellers, e.g. arranged at the side of the vessel
Arrangements of propulsive devices directly acting on air
Propulsive devices directly acted on by wind

titlePart.entryReference: air-driven propellers driving underwater propulsive elements

titlePart.text: using sails or like wind-catching surfaces
Connections of sails to masts, spars, or the like
Effecting propulsion by jets, i.e. reaction principle
titlePart.entryReference: power plant per se, see the relevant classes

titlePart.text: the propulsive medium being ambient water
having means for deflecting jet or influencing cross-section thereof
the propulsive medium being steam or other gas
the gas being produced by combustion
the gas being produced by other chemical processes
Effecting propulsion by wind motors driving water-engaging propulsive elements
Effecting propulsion by use of vessel-mounted driving mechanisms co-operating with anchored chains or the like

titlePart.entryReference: swimming frameworks with swimmer-operated driving mechanisms
land-based training equipment for rowing or sculling

titlePart.text: Other apparatus for converting muscle power into propulsive effort
titlePart.entryReference: general features of propulsion elements, see the relevant groups

titlePart.text: using hand levers, cranks, pedals, or the like, e.g. water cycles, boats propelled by boat-mounted pedal cycles
Effecting propulsion of vessels, not otherwise provided for
by using energy derived from movement of ambient water, e.g. from rolling or pitching of vessels
by discharging gas into ambient water
by direct engagement with water-bed or ground
Use of propulsion power plant or units on vessels
titlePart.entryReference: hull reinforcements for carrying propulsion power plant or units
propulsion power plant or units per se, see the relevant classes

noteParagraph.text: This group comprises arrangements of propulsion power plant or units on vessels, and to some extent it includes adaptations of such plant or units to facilitate such arrangements.

titlePart.text: relating to condensers or engine-cooling fluid heat-exchangers
the vessels being powered by nuclear energy
the vessels being powered by combinations of different types of propulsion units
the propulsion power units being controlled from exterior of engine room, e.g. from navigation bridge
the vessels being small craft, e.g. racing boats
Outboard propulsion power units movably installed for steering, reversing, tilting, or the like
Arrangements of transmission between propulsion power unit and propulsive element
Mounting of propulsion plant or unit, e.g. for anti-vibration purposes
titlePart.entryReference: vibration-dampers, suppression of vibration in systems

titlePart.text: Arrangements of propulsion power-unit exhaust uptakes

titlePart.entryReference: flue devices for furnaces in general

titlePart.text: Transmitting power from propulsion power plant to propulsive elements
titlePart.entryReference: adaptation of transmission to allow adjustment in location or direction of propellers
transmission between wind motors and propulsive elements

titlePart.text: the main transmitting element, e.g. shaft, being substantially vertical
for transmitting drive from a single propulsion power unit
for transmitting drive from more than one propulsion power unit
allowing combined use of the propulsion power units
with unidrectional drive or where reversal is immaterial
characterised by provision of reverse drive
for alternative use of the propulsion power units
with separate forward and astern propulsion power units, e.g. turbines

titlePart.entryReference: attachment of a member on a shaft in general

titlePart.text: Slowing-down otherwise than by use of propulsive elements
titlePart.entryReference: using adjustably-mounted propeller ducts or rings for steering

titlePart.text: Dynamic anchoring, i.e. positioning vessels by means of main or auxiliary propulsive elements
titlePart.entryReference: equipment to decrease pitch, roll, or like unwanted vessel movements by auxiliary jets or propellers
systems for waterborne-vessel position control , e.g.

titlePart.text: power driven, i.e. using steering engine
with alternative muscle or power- operated steering
Transmitting of movement of initiating means to steering engine

titlePart.entryReference: power units per se, see the relevant classes

titlePart.text: Transmitting of movement of engine to rudder, e.g. using quadrants, brakes
Steering or dynamic anchoring by propulsive elements
Steering or dynamic anchoring by propellers used therefor only
Steering or dynamic anchoring by rudders carrying propellers
Steering or slowing-down by extensible flaps or the like

Steering or slowing-down by deflection of propeller slip-stream otherwise than by rudder
